questions.text: A patient with a category-II dog bite presents to the trauma center on 2nd September 2022. After the local wound management, the patient has been prescribed a schedule for rabies vaccine administration. He marks the days when he is supposed to take the vaccine in a calendar as shown below.  Which regimen is likely prescribed to the patient? What is the route of administration in this case?
questions.solution:
The regimen prescribed here is the Essen regimen which is intramuscular.

Post-exposure prophylaxis regimen for rabies:

Intramuscular regimen: In this regimen, 1 ml or 0.5 ml of vaccine is injected into the deltoid in patients with category II and III wounds.

  • Essen regimen: It is a 5-dose regimen in which 1 dose of vaccine is given on days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28 each. (1,1,1,1,1)
  • Thai red cross regimen: It is a 4-dose multisite regimen in which 2 doses of vaccine are given on day 0, 3, 7, 28 each. (2-2-2-0-2)

Intradermal regimen: In this regimen, 0.1 ml of injection is given at 2 sites on days 0, 3, 7, and 28 each.

The following measures should be taken immediately to stop the contraction of rabies:

  • Cleansing - The most important step in the prevention of rabies is washing the affected area with plenty of soap and water under a running tap for 15 minutes. This is a standard procedure that minimizes the contraction of rabies.
  • Chemical treatment - Irrigation of the wound should then be done with virucidal agents like alcohol, tincture, 0.01% solution of aqueous iodine, or povidone-iodine. Even irrigating the wound with cetrimide + chlorhexidine solution can be done. This process eliminates the residual virus in the wound.
  • Suturing - Bite wounds are not sutured generally. If suturing is necessary, it is done after 24-48 hours under the cover of local infiltration of the rabies immunoglobulin which is generally done in category III wounds.
  • Other measures - Local antibiotics and tetanus toxoid should be given.

Different wound categories for post-exposure prophylaxis:

Categories of wound Post-exposure prophylaxis
Category I - touching or feeding animals, licks on intact skin None
Category II - nibbling of uncovered skin, minor scratches, or abrasions
without bleeding		 Immediate vaccination and
local treatment of the wound
Category III- single or multiple transdermal bites or scratches, licks on broken skin contacts with bats Immediate vaccination and
administration of rabies
immunoglobulin; local
treatment of the wound

 

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins (WHO guidelines)

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, GOI:

Individuals with WHO category II or III exposures should receive PEP without delay.

One ID dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one IM dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • RIG provides a passive immunization and is administered only once, as soon as possible after the initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine.
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight.
  • WHO has recommended the use of Monoclonal Antibodies (mAb) as a “cocktail” containing at least two antibodies against RABV, as alternatives for RIGs in PEP.
  • All of the rabies immunoglobulin, or as much as anatomically possible (but avoiding possible compartment syndrome), should be administered into or around the wound site or sites. The remaining immunoglobulin, if any, should be injected intramuscularly at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration. Rabies immunoglobulin may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.
  • Prioritization of RIG allocation: Multiple bites>Deep wounds>Bites to head, neck, and hands>Patients with severe immunodeficiency>The biting animal is confirmed or probable rabies>Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat.

(PrEP)Pre-exposure prophylaxis

  • PrEP considered in remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult, the dog bite incidence is >5% per year or vampire bat rabies are known to be present.
  • Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of three intramuscular (IM) or intradermal (ID) doses are given on days 0, 7, and 21 or 28. For adults, the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm; for young children (under 1 year of age), the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended. Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.
  • For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous complete PrEP or PEP the following guidelines would be applicable:
    • Proper wound management should be done.
    • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
    • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.
    Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP or PrEP within the last three months.
    • People who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccine of unproven potency or cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment should be treated as a fresh case and given full PEP.

questions.text: A neonate presents with feeding difficulty and failure to thrive. Her urine has a peculiar burnt sugar odour due to an excess of branched-chain amino acids. Which of the following amino acid is not restricted in this neonate's diet?
questions.solution:
In maple syrup urine disease (MSUD), only branched-chain amino acids are restricted, hence, methionine does not need any restriction in diet.

Branched-chain amino acids are:

  • Leucine (L)
  • Isoleucine (I)
  • Valine (V)

MSUD is an autosomal recessive disorder in which there is a partial or complete deficiency of branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase complex (BCKD). This impairs the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids. These amino acids, particularly leucine and their metabolite accumulate in the blood, causing toxic effects on the brain. Features include feeding problems, vomiting, ketosis, and a characteristic burnt sugar odour/maple syrup-like odour of urine, sweat, and cerumen.

Laboratory investigations will show increased levels of branched-chain amino acids in the plasma and urine. Leucine levels are usually higher than isoleucine, and valine.

Treatment involves restricted intake of branched-chain amino acids using commercially available formulas and judicious supplementation of isoleucine and valine. Very high levels of leucine are removed by hemodialysis.

Related Pearl: Amino acid Enzymatic Disorders and the Associated Enzymes

Disorder

Enzyme defect

Phenylketonuria

Phenylalanine hydroxylase

Tyrosinosis (Tyrosinemia type I)

Maleyl Acetate isomerase or Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase

Maple syrup urine disease 

Branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase(BCKAD)

Alkaptonuria

Homogentisate oxidase

Albinism

Tyrosinase

Homocystinuria type I

Cystathionine synthase

Homocystinuria type II

Defect in methylcobalamin formation

Cystathioninuria

Cystathionase

Tyrosinemia type II or Richner-Hanhart syndrome

Tyrosine transaminase or Tyrosine aminotransferase

Primary hyperoxaluria

Alanine glyoxalate aminotransferase

Hypervalinemia

Valine transaminase

Isovaleric acidemia

Isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase

Histidinemia

Histidase

Hyperprolinemia type I

Proline oxidase

questions.text: A 23-year-old football player is brought unresponsive to the emergency room following trauma to the head. His teammates recall that he was alert and responsive for a brief period in the locker room before he became unconscious. CT head was suggestive of an epidural hematoma. What is the definitive management for his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing lens-shaped hemorrhage is consistent with acute epidural hematoma. Craniotomy with emergency evacuation of the hematoma is the definitive management of this condition.

Extradural hematoma (EDH) is also known as an epidural hematoma. It is a collection of blood between the outer layer of the dura and the inner surface of the skull which is called the periosteal layer. The bleeding is most commonly due to torn middle meningeal artery.

EDH is commonly associated with a history of trauma and associated skull fracture.  It is associated with an underlying fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone.

Epidural hematoma may present with a transient loss of consciousness immediately following the trauma followed by a lucid interval, where consciousness is recovered. The patient subsequently worsens his neurological status due to continued bleeding from the site as seen in this patient. It can cause a mass effect with herniation

EDH is diagnosed with CT and MRI. CT image shows the typical bi-convex hyperdense lesion not crossing cranial sutures, but can cross venous sinuses.

The definitive management for any patient with GCS<9 and pupillary abnormalities such as anisocoria is craniotomy with emergency evacuation of the hematoma. Surgery is also recommended for patients with worsening neurological status and hematoma volume >30ml regardless of neurological status

The image given below shows a CT scan depicting EDH. Note the biconvex or lens-shaped hematoma.

Other options:

Option A: Hyperventilation lowers the pCO2 and lowers the intracranial pressure (ICP) because of vasoconstriction. But this may also worsen the perfusion in the brain and must be done with caution.

Option B: Intravenous mannitol may be used to lower ICP but it is not a definitive management option in this patient in a coma.

Option D: Intravenous fluids are not indicated in this condition. It may be used as an adjunct in therapy.

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hemorrhage (ICH)

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH): 

  • Source: Arterial bleed
  • MC- Middle meningeal artery 
  • Cause- Trauma 
  • Clinical features: Lucid interval is characteristic 
  • CT – Lentiform opacity 
  • Treatment: A large or rapidly evolving EDH requires surgical evacuation

 

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous bleed 
  • Bridging dural veins 
  • Causes: Trauma, anticoagulants, antiplatelets, alcohol abuse, shaken baby syndrome 
  • Clinical features
    • Acute SDH: may be associated with lucid interval
    • Chronic SDH: drowsiness, headache
  • CT- crescentic opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)

  • Source: Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – Trauma
    • 2nd MC – Rupture of berry aneurysm
  • MC sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery 
  • Clinical features: Thunderclap headache with neck stiffness +/- FND 
  • Investigations:
    • Non-contrast CT brain,
    • CSF xanthochromia (peaks in 2 days and subsides in 2 weeks) 
  • Treatment:
    • Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm,
    • Triple H therapy – hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution to prevent vasospasm 

 

Intraparenchymal hemorrhage- (MC type of ICH)

  • Source- Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – hypertension
    • Trauma, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, bleeding disorders, neoplasms, vascular malformations 
  • MC sites:
    • Putamen (basal ganglia)
    • Thalamus
    • Cerebellum
    • Pons 
  • Treatment:
    • Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP or fresh platelets as required
    • Surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoms >3 cm in size

questions.text: In a live donor kidney transplantation, the donor's renal artery should be anastomosed with which of the following?

choices.text: End-to-end anastomosis with internal iliac artery
End-to-side anastomosis with internal iliac artery
End-to-end anastomosis with external iliac artery
End-to-side anastomosis with external iliac artery

questions.solution:
In a live donor kidney transplantation, the donor's renal artery is end-to-end anastomosed with the recipient's internal iliac artery.

In the renal transplant, the renal vessels are anastomosed as follows:

  Living donor Cadaveric donor
Anastomosis End-to-end End-to-side
Recipient artery Internal iliac artery External iliac artery
Recipient vein External iliac vein External iliac vein

The below image shows the different types of anastomosis in kidney transplantation from live and deceased donors.

The usual site for kidney transplantation is the iliac fossa in the retroperitoneal position, making it a heterotopic type of transplantation. The diseased kidney is left in situ.

The optimal cold storage time for the kidney is 18 hours, and the maximum safe cold storage time for the kidney is 36 hours.

Optimal and maximum safe cold storage time for various organs are as follows:

Organs Optimal time (hours) Maximum time (hours)
1) Kidney <18 <36
2) Liver <12 <18
3) Pancreas <10 <18
4) Small intestine <4 <6
5) Heart <3 <6
6) Lungs <3 <8

Note: 

In orthotopic graft/transplantation, the graft is placed in its normal anatomical site. However, in heterotopic graft/transplantation, the graft is placed at a site different from its normal anatomical site.

questions.text: Match the following endoscopic images with their respective diagnoses?

choices.text: A- Barrett's esophagus, B- Mallory Weiss tear
A- Mallory Weiss tear, B- Barrett's esophagus
A- Crohn’s Disease, B- Ulcerative Colitis
A- Ulcerative Colitis, B- Crohn’s Disease

questions.solution:
Image A is of ulcerative colitis and image B is of Crohn's disease.

The given image A shows continuous involvement of mucosa with no normal mucosa in between which indicates ulcerative colitis. Fistula is not a complication of ulcerative colitis. 

Image B shows a cobblestone appearance seen in Crohn's disease. Normal mucosa in between the ulcers leads to this appearance. Fine granular mucosa is the earliest barium enema finding in Ulcerative colitis. Fistula is seen with Crohn’s disease.

Barrett's esophagus is a condition in which the mucosal lining of the swallowing tube that connects the mouth to the stomach (esophagus) becomes damaged by acid reflux, which causes the lining to thicken and become red. It is associated with an increased risk of developing esophageal cancer.

A Mallory-Weiss tear is a tear of the tissue of your lower esophagus most often caused by violent coughing or vomiting.

questions.text: Identify the type of wound from the image.
questions.solution:
The given image shows irregular and ragged cut wounds over the palmar surface of the hands and fingers, which is suggestive of defense wounds.

Defense wounds are the wounds that occur as a result of the victim's attempt to save himself from an injury.

It can be active or passive. Active defense wounds occur when the victim tries to grasp the weapon, while passive wounds result when the victim raises the hands, arms, or legs in an attempt to protect the eyes, head, or neck.

The morphology of the wound depends upon the type of weapon and the attack. In a sharp injury due to a single-edged weapon, a single cut may be seen on the palm or the bends of fingers. In the case of a double-edged sharp weapon, cuts are seen on both the palm and fingers. The cuts are irregular in-depth and ragged.

The defense wounds signify homicide, and in females, they often indicate sexual assault. 

Other options:

Options B and C: Antemortem and postmortem wounds are of medicolegal importance while evaluating trauma. They can be differentiated by the following features:

Feature Antemortem wounds Postmortem wounds
Edges Swollen edges with wound gapes Closely approximated with no wound gapes 
Hemorrhage Arterial type of hemorrhage Venous hemorrhage
Spurting Spurting of blood seen with firmly coagulated blood No spurts and no clotting 
Vital reaction Inflammation and repair seen No signs of inflammation and repair

Option D: Hesitation cuts are a feature of self-inflicted wounds or suicide. It typically appears as multiple, small, and superficial wounds on the skin, at the beginning of an incised wound. The common sites are the throat, wrist, and front of the chest.

questions.text: A diagnostic test has specificity of 0.80 and sensitivity of 0.90 when the prevalence of the disease in a population is 30%. What is the negative predictive value of the test?
questions.solution:
The Negative Predictive value is 95%

For convenience, assume the total population in this scenario is 100.

Total diseased population would then be 30 and disease free would be 70.

Since sensitivity is 0.90, total true positives (TP) would be 27.

Since specificity is 0.80, total true negatives (TN) would be 56.

The hypothetical table would be:

 

Disease +

Disease -

Total

Test +

27 (TP)

14 (FP)

41

Test -

3 (FN)

56 (TN)

59

Total

30

70

100

 Negative predictive value (NPV) = TN/(FN + TN) x 100 = 56/59 = 0.949 = 95%.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ Accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Speciifity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman delivered a healthy baby at 38 weeks of gestation. Twenty minutes later, the mother developed severe shortness of breath and appeared cyanotic. Her ECG and chest X-ray showed no abnormalities. Despite resuscitation, she died after a few hours. Her lab reports revealed the following findings. What is the most probable diagnosis?
Platelets Low
Fibrinogen Low
Thrombin time Increased
Prothrombin time Increased
Partial thromboplastin time Increased
Fibrin degradation products Increased
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is amniotic fluid embolism. The given lab evaluation points to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). 

Amniotic fluid embolism presents with a classic triad of hemodynamic and respiratory compromise, along with DIC. Usually, it presents during the late stages of labour or immediate postpartum (peripartum period). Gasping for air, seizures, and cardiorespiratory arrest are other features. Other causes for a similar presentation such as myocardial infarction, pulmonary embolism, and anaphylactic shock needs to be ruled out. 

According to the American Society for Maternal-Fetal Medicine, the diagnostic criteria for amniotic fluid embolism include:

  • Sudden onset cardiorespiratory arrest, or both hypotension and respiratory compromise
  • Overt DIC
  • Onset during labour or within 30 minutes of delivery of the placenta
  • No fever (≥38°C)

The currently accepted mechanism is the entry of fetal material into the maternal circulation which leads to the activation of proinflammatory mediator systems. This results in pulmonary vasoconstriction and hypertension. The tissue factor present in fetal material also activates factor VII resulting in DIC.

Risk factors include rapid labour, meconium-stained liquor, cesarean delivery, placenta previa, eclampsia, placental abruption, polyhydramnios, uterine tears, post-term pregnancy, and advanced maternal age.

The condition can be fatal and management includes cardiopulmonary resuscitation and advanced cardiac life support.

Autopsy findings as shown in the image below, include the presence of squamous cells shed from the fetal skin, lanugo hair, fat from vernix caseosa, and mucin derived from the fetal respiratory or gastrointestinal tract in the maternal pulmonary microvasculature.

 

Other options:

Option A: Preeclampsia is characterized by the development of hypertension to the extent of 140/90 mm Hg or more with proteinuria, after the 20th week of gestation, in a previously normotensive and non-proteinuric woman. Pre-eclampsia causes endothelial injury which in turn leads to DIC.

Option B: Tension pneumothorax can be a possible diagnosis with the patient's clinical symptoms. But a normal chest X-ray would make this diagnosis unlikely. 

Option C: Bacterial sepsis leads to endothelial injury and release of phospholipids, which in turn leads to DIC. The tissue factor that is released in response to cytokines (IL-1), tumor necrosis factor, and endotoxin. The tissue factor activates the extrinsic pathway leading to coagulopathy. Given the patient's history, an amniotic fluid embolism is more likely.

questions.text: The HACEK group of bacteria includes all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Corynebacterium jeikeium is not included in HACEK group.

HACEK organisms are fastidious, gram-negative bacteria. They are slow growing and requires a carbon dioxide atmosphere. They do not grow on routine media used for enteric bacteria like MacConkey agar.

The HACEK group of bacteria includes

  • Haemophilus species
  • Aggregatibacter species
  • Cardiobacterium hominis
  • Eikenella corrodens
  • Kingella kingae

These organisms are present in the oral cavity as part of the normal respiratory microbiota. Eikenella and Cardiobacterium species have been recovered from the gastrointestinal tract and female genital tract. They cause infective endocarditis.

Haemophilus parainfluenzae is the most common Haemophilus species that is isolated from HACEK endocarditis cases.

Note:

  • The species Haemophilus aphrophilus, and Haemophilus paraphrophilus have been combined into a single species, aphrophilus, and placed under the genus Aggregatibacter.
  • Haemophilus segnis and Actinobacillus actinomycetemcomitans have also been added to the genus Aggregatibacter.

Related Pearl: Microbiology of Infective Endocarditis

NOTE :

*CoNS includes Staphylococcus epidermidis and other coagulase-negative types

*Streptococci includes Viridans streptococci (VGS), Streptococcus gallolyticus (previously Streptococcus bovis biotype 1) and other non-groupable and groupable streptococci

questions.text: A patient presented with palpitations and features of right heart failure. Family history is positive for sudden cardiac death in his brother. His ECG is given below. The marked changes in the image are described as:
questions.solution:
The changes marked in ECG show a notched deflection at the end of the QRS complex due to delayed ventricular activation known as an epsilon wave. It is commonly seen in patients with arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC).

ARVC is autosomal dominant cardiomyopathy characterised by fibrofatty replacement in the myocardium of the ventricles. It most commonly affects the right ventricle. It is due to mutations in the gene encoding desmosome-associated protein plakophilin 2. This leads to defective cell-adhesion proteins in the desmosomes that link adjacent cardiac myocytes.

The patients usually present with rhythm disturbances, right-sided heart failure, and sudden cardiac death. ARVC is associated with Naxos syndrome. This syndrome is characterised by arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy and hyperkeratosis of the palmar and the plantar surfaces. 

Morphology shows severe thinning of the right ventricular wall due to loss of myocytes, accompanied by extensive fatty infiltration and fibrosis. In ARVC, there is T inversion and delayed ventricular activation manifesting as epsilon waves.

Other options:

Option A: Delta wave is the slurred upstroke of the QRS complex as seen during ventricular pre-excitation, a feature of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome. 

Option C: Osborn waves may be seen in the ECG of patients with systemic hypothermia, hypercalcemia, brain injury, subarachnoid hemorrhage, cardiopulmonary arrest from oversedation, vasospastic angina, or idiopathic ventricular fibrillation. They are observed as a hump-like elevation at the junction of the QRS complex and ST segment. An alteration in the ventricular transmural action potential is attributed to their appearance on an ECG.

Option D: Saw-tooth wave is seen in atrial flutter. It is caused due to repetitive atrial excitation caused by large re-entry impulses circulating within the atrial myocardium. 

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text: A doctor is taking history from a diabetic patient and decides to make a chart to assess joint involvement. Which chart should he make to explain this?
questions.solution:
A tree diagram is used mainly in to chart the possible outcomes of a sample event.

In this case, a tree diagram would help the doctor in explaining the possible outcomes to the patient’s diabetes, with the perspective of joint involvement.

The following image shows the outline of a tree diagram:

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A pressure-volume diagram of the left ventricle is given below. Calculate the stroke volume considering the heart rate as 65 beats per minute.
questions.solution:
The stroke volume of this pressure-volume diagram is 70 mL.

The points in the graph indicate the following events of the cardiac cycle:

  • Point 1: Opening of the mitral valve. The corresponding reading on the graph denotes end-systolic volume (ESV).
  • Point 2: Closing of the mitral valve. The corresponding reading on the graph denotes end-diastolic volume (EDV).
  • Point 3: Opening of the aortic valve.
  • Point 4: Closing of the aortic valve.

Stroke volume is the amount of blood that the heart pumps out with each beat. It is about 70 mL from each ventricle in resting conditions.

In a pressure-volume diagram, stroke volume (SV) can be calculated using the values of ESV (50 mL) and EDV (120 mL):

Stroke volume = End diastolic volume – End systolic volume

Therefore, SV = 120 - 50 = 70 mL.

Cardiac output can be calculated from the given data using the formula:  Cardiac output = Stroke volume x heart rate

Therefore, in this case, cardiac output = 70 x 65 = 4550 mL.

questions.text: What would be the average duration of lochial discharge in a puerperal woman?
questions.solution:
The average duration of lochial discharge in a postpartum woman is about 24-36 days. The average amount of discharge for the first week is 250 mL.

The lochial discharge appears as follows:

Name Colour Timing after delivery Content
Lochia rubra Red First few days  Blood, decidua, fetal membranes, vernix, lanugo, meconium
Lochia serosa Yellowish/Pink After 3-4 days

WBC, cervical mucus, microorganisms
Lochia alba Pale White After 10th day Decidua, cells, WBC, mucin, cholesterol crystals, and fat cells

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic is  having double vision with downward gaze .  She has no other complaints. What could be the reason for the symptoms?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests trochlear nerve palsy.

In 4th nerve palsy, the superior oblique is affected, causing:

  • The weakness of depression in eye: Mainly seen when the eye is adducted (depression during abducted position is a function of Inferior rectus)
  • Weakness of abduction in eye
  • Failure of intorsion: Cause of diplopia

The main actions of the superior oblique are intorsion (incyclotorsion), and depression in adduction.

Hence, the patient will have difficulty in looking downwards when the eyes are in an adducted position. Diabetes, hypertension, and atherosclerosis affect the vasa nervosum of the cranial nerves leading to ischemia of the nerves. It results in paralysis.

Other options:

Option B: In 3rd nerve palsy (oculomotor nerve) - Due to the involvement of the superior rectus and medial rectus, elevation and adduction will also be impaired, which is not the case here.

Option D: In 6th nerve palsy (abducens nerve) - Due to the involvement of only the lateral rectus, abduction will be impaired and not depression.

Related Pearl: Origins of cranial nerves at the base of the brain

Cranial nerve origins as seen in gross anatomy:

  • III cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus.  
  • IV cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus - the only nerve the exits from the dorsal aspect
  • V cranial nerve: The substance of pons 
  • VI, VII, and VIII cranial nerves:  Pontomedullary junction
  • IX, X, and XI cranial nerves(nucleus ambiguus): Posterolateral sulcus   
  • XII cranial nerve: Anterolateral sulcus (between pyramid and olive)

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with frequently changing bowel habits. He noticed blood in the stools which were not associated with pain. There was no history of weight loss. Barium enema shows multiple outpouchings in the ascending, transverse, and descending colon resembling a saw-tooth.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is colonic diverticulosis.

The above clinical scenario with the barium enema image is suggestive of colonic diverticulosis. The barium enema shows multiple outpouchings in the ascending, transverse, and descending colon resembling a saw-tooth, indicating diverticulosis.  

Diverticulosis refers to the condition where multiple outpouchings occur along the gastrointestinal tract without any inflammation. Colonic diverticulosis is more common among the age group of more than 50 years. Colonic diverticulosis is primarily false diverticula as only the mucosa and muscularis mucosa have herniated. Due to the high intraluminal pressure, they are referred to as the pulsion type of diverticula. A low fibre diet results in smaller stool volume that increases intraluminal pressure for propulsion. The higher pressures get directed to the colonic wall resulting in pulsion diverticula. The sigmoid colon is the most common location.

The majority of the patients with diverticulosis are usually asymptomatic. However, some patients may present with abdominal cramps, altered bowel habits, and painless rectal bleeding. Diverticulosis can present with complications like:

  • Diverticulitis
  • Abscess
  • Peritonitis
  • Intestinal obstruction
  • Hemorrhage 
  • Fistula formation

Diagnosis:

The diagnosis is confirmed by a colonoscopy or an X-ray barium enema. Barium enema radiograph shows multiple barium-coated outpouchings from the colonic wall and gives the appearance of a saw-tooth. In cases of severe abdominal pain, a CT scan is preferred to avoid the risk of intestinal perforation.

The saw-tooth appearence is seen below:

 

Treatment:

A high fibre diet reduces the incidence of diverticulosis. Antispasmodics can be prescribed to reduce intestinal spasms. Most cases of bleeding are self-limiting. If persistent bleeding is present, surgical, endoscopic or radiological interventions can be done to reduce the bleeding.

Other options:

Option B- Carcinoma colon shows apple-core sign on barium enema as shown below. 

 

Option C- Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that shows the string sign of Kantor on barium enema as shown below.

 

Option D- Intussusception shows the coiled-spring appearance on barium enema as shown below.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following routes of administration in the descending order of systemic absorption of local anesthetic.
  1. Subcutaneous injection
  2. Injection into brachial plexus
  3. Intercostal nerve blockade 
  4. Injection into lumbar epidural space
questions.solution:
Routes of administration in the descending order of systemic absorption of local anesthetic:

  1. Intercostal nerve blockade 
  2. Injection into the caudal epidural space
  3. Injection into lumbar epidural space
  4. Injection into brachial plexus
  5. Subcutaneous injection

Systemic absorption of local anesthetic is determined by the

  • Site of injection and its tissue blood perfusion
  • Dosage and volume of drug administered
  • Vasoconstrictor agent addition
  • The pharmacologic properties of the agent itself

Exposure to an area of greater vascularity would result in a greater rate and degree of absorption of local anesthetic. The clinical significance of this is that the use of a fixed dose of a local anesthetic agent can be potentially toxic in one area of administration but not in others.

Ex:- Lidocaine without epinephrine for an intercostal nerve block results in average peak venous plasma levels that are sufficiently high to cause symptoms of CNS toxicity. But the same dose of lidocaine when used for a brachial plexus block results in blood levels that are rarely associated with toxicity.

 

Related Pearl: Systemic Absorbtion of Local Anaesthetic in the Order of Occurrence

Systemic absorption of a local anesthetic depends on vascularity.

And thereby highest blood concentrations are seen following

  • Intravenous (intraarterial) injection, followed by
  • Tracheal injection
  • Intercostal nerve blockade
  • Paracervical
  • Caudal epidural block
  • Lumbar epidural block
  • Brachial plexus block
  • Sciatic block
  • and is least with subcutaneous injection

questions.text: A neonate presented with features of intestinal obstruction. The X-ray showed the following image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above plain abdominal radiograph shows a typical double-bubble sign suggestive of duodenal atresia.

The double-bubble represents dilatation of the stomach and the proximal duodenum.

The most common cause of neonatal intestinal obstruction is duodenal atresia. The incidence is 1 in 6000 to 10,000 live births. Duodenal atresia is thought to occur as a result of the failure of vacuolization of the duodenum from its solid cord stage.

It is associated with several conditions, such as:

  • Prematurity
  • Down's syndrome
  • Maternal polyhydramnios
  • Malrotation
  • Annular pancreas
  • Biliary atresia. 

The duodenal obstruction is distal to the ampulla of Vater in most cases therefore the infant infants present with bilious vomiting.

Treatment is by duodenoduodenostomy.

Other options:

Option A: Jejunoileal atresia would present with a triple-bubble sign.

Option B: Esophageal atresia would present with a pouch like finding on the scan.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

questions.text: A mutation in the gene for aquaporin channel leads to
questions.solution:
A mutation in the gene for the aquaporin channel leads to nephrogenic DI.

Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI) is an inability to concentrate urine due to impaired renal tubule response to vasopressin (ADH), which leads to the excretion of large amounts of dilute urine.

Related Pearl: Causes of Nephrogenic DI

A) Genetic

  • X linked recessive and autosomal dominant or recessive due to mutations in the aquaporin channel

B) Acquired

  • Drugs
    • Lithium
    • Demeclocycline
    • Methoxyflurane
    • Amphotericin B
    • Aminoglycosides
    • Cisplatin
    • Rifampin
    • Foscarnet
  • Metabolic
    • Hypercalcemia, hypercalciuria
    • Hypokalemia
  • Obstruction (ureter or urethra)
  • Vascular
    • Sickle cell disease and trait
    • Ischemia (acute tubular necrosis)
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Sarcoma
  • Amyloidosis

questions.text: A 20-year-old college student comes to the emergency room with a history of palpitations, sweating and a feeling of impending doom for the past 45 minutes while preparing for his exam. He gives a previous history of similar complaints. There is no history of medical illness or substance abuse. Which of the following should be given in the acute management of his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a panic attack. Benzodiazepines such as alprazolam are used to treat panic attacks.

A panic attack is a sudden period of intense fear or apprehen­sion that may last from minutes to hours. Panic attacks can occur in panic disorders, specific phobia, social phobia and post-traumatic stress disorder. They may occur at any time and are not associated with any identifiable stimulus.

Some habits predispose a patient to panic attacks. These include use of caffeine, alcohol, nicotine, or other substances, and unusual patterns of sleeping or eating. 

 The first panic attack is often spontaneous, although panic attacks occasionally follow excitement, physical exertion, sexual activity, or moderate emotional trauma. 

The major symptoms are extreme fear and a sense of impending death and doom. Physi­cal signs often include tachycardia, palpitations, dyspnea or hyperventilation, and sweating. Patients often try to leave whatever situation they are in to seek help. The attack generally lasts 20 to 30 minutes and rarely more than an hour. Hyperventilation can produce respiratory alkalosis and other symptoms.

For rapid control of symptoms, alprazolam is the drug of choice. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors such as paroxetine are started concurrently and alprazolam is slowly tapered. Fluoxetine is used for panic attacks with co-morbid depression.

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

Disorder 
Feature
Panic disorder
1. Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with ≥ 4 of the following:
  • Dyspnea
  • Tachypnea
  • Palpitations
  • Sweating
  • Dizziness
  • Chest pain
  • Tightness
  • Paresthesias
  • Emotional and cognitive
    symptoms
  • Feeling that something catastrophic is
    about to happen.

2. At least 1 attack followed by one or both of the following > 1 month:

  • Worry about an additional panic attack or consequences
  • Changes in behaviour related to attacks (ex: avoidance)

3. Panic attack not attributable to substance abuse or another medical condition.

4. Panic attack not explained by another mental disorder.

Treatment of Panic disorder:

Immediate: Benzodiazepines
Long term: SSRI/ SNRI and or cognitive behavioural therapy
Phobias
Exaggerated anxiety responses that occur
during exposure to relatively innocuous stimuli or situations.
Specific phobias entail phobic responses to
particular stimuli or situations.
Social
anxiety disorder (Social phobia)
Phobic responses to specific social situations.
Generalized anxiety disorder
Excessive worry about
a variety of topics (job, health, finances, etc.) > 6 months.
 
3 or more of the following symptoms:
  • Restlessness
  • Fatigue
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Irritability
  • Muscle tension
  • Sleep disturbance

Treatment:

First line: CBT, SSRIs or SNRIs

Second-line: Benzodiazepines, Buspirone

questions.text: Which of the following cardiac features would make the diagnosis of tricuspid atresia unlikely?
questions.solution:
Left ventricular hypoplasia would make the diagnosis unlikely as right ventricular hypoplasia is seen in tricuspid atresia.

Other features of tricuspid atresia:

  • An increased left ventricular impulse is noted in contrast to an increased right ventricular impulse seen in most other cyanotic diseases.
  • A VSD holosystolic murmur is audible along the left sternal border.
  • The second heart sound (S2) is usually single.
  • Left ventricular hypertrophy and left axis deviation on ECG.
  • Tall, peaked P waves on lead II known as Himalayan P waves which are suggestive of an enlarged right atrium. 

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or Figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text:
A 60- year old patient who presented with high-grade fever, productive cough and breathlessness, was found to have decreased breath sounds and a dull note on percussion on the left side. His chest radiograph showed the following findings. Which of the following pleural fluid characteristics will suggest a bacterial aetiology?

(Take upper limit of normal serum LDH as 240 U/L)

choices.text: Pleural fluid LDH/ Serum LDH is 0.5
Pleural fluid protein/ Serum protein is 0.4
Pleural fluid LDH/ upper limit of normal serum LDH is 0.7

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of pneumonia. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH of >0.6 is a characteristic of the pleural fluid which is associated with exudative effusion. The pleural effusion associated with bacterial pneumonia is exudative in nature. 

Pleural effusion refers to the pathological accumulation of fluid in the pleural space due to:

  • excess fluid formation from the interstitial spaces of lung, parietal pleura or peritoneal cavity
  • decreased fluid removal by the lymphatics

Pleural effusion may present with:

  • dyspnea
  • pleuritic pain
  • dry cough
  • associated symptoms like fever, weight loss, edema, ascites depending on the etiology

On examination, there may be:

  • tachypnea, in a large effusion
  • dullness to persussion
  • decreased/absent breath sounds at the base(s)
  • other signs present vary with the underlying etiology

Etiology of pleural effusion can be:

  • Exudative: Due to a disruption in pleural fluid formation and drainage because of local factors. Examples are:
    • Malignancy
    • Infections
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Rheumatic diseases like rheumatoid arthritis, SLE, amyloidosis
    • Meig's syndrome
    • Drugs like nitrofurantoin, dantrolene, amiodarone, methotrexate, clozapine, phenytoin and beta blockers
    • Radiation-induced
    • Haemothorax
    • Chylothorax
  • Transudative: Due to a disruption in pleural fluid formation and drainage due to systemic factors. Examples are:
    • Congestive heart failure
    • Hepatic cirrhosis
    • Nephrotic Syndrome
    • SVC obstruction
    • Peritoneal dialysis
    • Myxedema

Light’s criteria can be used to differentiate between transudative and exudative pleural effusions. Exudative effusions will meet at least one of the following criteria:

  1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein >0.5
  2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH >0.6
  3. Pleural fluid LDH is more than two-thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum. 

Recommended tests for all diagnostic thoracocentesis include:

  • Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and protein
  • Microscopy and culture
  • Cytology and differential count
  • Glucose, pH, triglycerides, amylase, haematocrit, AFB culture and PCR can be done if a particular etiology is suspected.

If the difference between the protein levels in the serum and the pleural fluid > 3.1 g/dL, it is likely to be transudative pleural effusion. If the glucose levels are less than 60mg/dL, then the effusion is likely due to exudative causes like malignancy, bacterial infections (parapneumonic effusion), and rheumatoid pleuritis.

If the pleural fluid cytology, culture, glucose, and staining do not yield any result, perform spiral CT to rule out pulmonary embolism and assess the markers of tuberculosis.

Other investigations include:

  • Chest X-Ray
  • Chest ultrasound
  • Chest CT
  • Thoracocentesis
  • Invasive diagnostic procedures like pleural biopsy, video-assisted thoracoscopy and bronchoscopy are performed in case of inconclusive diagnosis.

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction
  • Myxedema 
  • Urinothorax

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Neoplastic disease: metastatic disease and mesothelioma
  • Infectious disease
  • Pulmonary embolization
  • GI: Esophageal perforation, pancreatic disease, intraabdominal abscess etc.,
  • Collagen vascular disease: SLE, rheumatoid pleuritis, Wegener's, Churg Strauss syndrome etc.,
  • Post coronary bypass surgery
  • Asbestos exposure
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Drug-induced pleural disease: nitrofurantoin, dantrolene, bromocriptine, amiodarone etc.,
  • Radiation therapy
  • Hemothorax
  • Chylothorax

questions.text: A 32-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with oral ulcers and a burning sensation in his oral cavity. A picture of the oral cavity is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the given scenario of a 32-year-old chronic alcoholic with oral ulcers and a burning sensation and the image showing white lesions on the oral cavity is leukoplakia. 

Leukoplakia is a premalignant condition of the oral cavity characterized by whitish patches or plaques that cannot be rubbed off.  

They appear as small, well-circumscribed lesions and can extensively involve a large area of the oral mucosa.

Variants of leukoplakia are

  • Speckled leukoplakia is whitish lesions on an erythematous base. They have the highest risk of malignant transformation. 
  • Proliferative verrucous leukoplakia is rare and has a high risk for malignant transformation.

Management includes smoking cessation and reduction in alcohol consumption. A biopsy should be done and a photographic record of the lesion is used for follow-up.

Other premalignant conditions of the oral cavity are erythroplakia and oral submucosal fibrosis.

Other Options:

Option B:  Erythroplakia ( refers to irregular, reddish velvety plaques on the oral cavity. The surface may be nodular and may bleed. It has a high risk of malignant transformation. Biopsy should be done followed by surgical ablation.

Option C: Oral submucosal fibrosis  is characterized by the formation of fibrous bands beneath the oral cavity. The disease is progressive and causes limitation of mouth opening and restricted tongue movements. Intralesional steroids and surgical excision of fibrous bands are recommended. 

Option D: Malakoplakia  is a rare inflammatory condition affecting immunocompromised individuals. It mainly affects the urinary tract but can involve any organ system. The clinical presentation includes tender ulcerations, nodules, papules, and plaques or fungating masses with perianal and genital skin involvement. Systemic antibiotics and surgical excision are recommended.

questions.text: A newborn has a deformity in the left arm as shown in the image below. The child was born after a difficult vaginal delivery. Which of the following nerve is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the image showing a claw hand with a supinated forearm and the flexed elbow is likely suggestive of Klumpke's palsy. The C8-T1 nerve roots are affected in this condition. 

Klumpke's palsy occurs following an injury to the 8th cervical nerve and the 1st thoracic nerve. It is commonly seen after deliveries involving excessive traction on the brachial plexus. It results in a paralyzed hand where the intrinsic muscles of the hand (T1) and the ulnar flexors of the wrist and fingers (C8) are mainly affected.

Clinically, the baby lies with the forearm supinated and the elbow flexed. There is a loss of intrinsic muscle power and reflexes in the hand. There may be a unilateral Horner’s syndrome, characterized by ipsilateral ptosis and miosis if the sympathetic fibers of the 1st thoracic root are also injured.

Immobilization and prevention of contractures form the mainstay of treatment in Klumpke's palsy.

The image given below shows clinical features seen in Klumpke's palsy.

Other options: 

Option A: Median nerve palsy presentation depends on the level of the lesion. Low lesions present as impaired abduction of the thumb and loss of sensation over the radial 3 1/2 digits. High lesions will have the features of low lesions, but will also have paralysis of the radial wrist flexors and forearm pronator muscles. The hand will be held with the ulnar fingers flexed and the index straight (pointing index sign). 

Option B: In a total plexus injury, C5 - T1 are injured. Here, the baby's arm is flail and pale. There is paralysis of all the fingers and unilateral Horner's syndrome. 

Option D: C5 - C6 injury is seen in Erb's palsy. It is typically seen in overweight babies with shoulder dystocia at delivery. There is paralysis of the abductors, external rotators of the shoulder, and the supinators. The arm will be held to the side in internal rotation and pronation with loss of finger extension.

The following image shows the clinical presentation of Erb's palsy.

Related Pearl: Erb's and Klumpke's Palsies.

Features Erb's palsy Klumpke's Palsy
Causes

Undue separtion of head and shoulder. Upper plexus root involved. 

Eg.Shoulder dystocia at delivery, motor vehicle accidents

Hyperabduction of shoulder. Lower plexus root involved.

Eg. Difficult breech delivery, Holding on to something (e.g. a branch) during a fall, Cervical rib syndrome, Scalene syndrome
Nerves roots  C5 and C6 C8 and T1
Muscles involved

Deltoid, Supraspinatus - loss of abduction 

Infraspinatus - loss of lateral rotation 

Biceps brachii - loss of flexion and supination 

 All intrinsic muscles of the hand
Position of the upper limb/hand Policeman's tip/Waiter's tip/ Porter's tip position Claw hand
Sensory loss +/- Along the outer aspect of the arm Along the medial border of forearm and hand
ANS signs  Absent

Horner syndrome

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with numerous itchy skin lesions on his chest and back which show characteristic collarette scales. 2 weeks prior to this he had noticed a round, scaly, erythematous lesion as shown in the image given below, on his thigh. Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: More common in children and young adults
Associated with viruses like HHV- 6 and HHV-7
Topical steroids can be used to relieve pruritus

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, with the image showing a herald patch, is suggestive of pityriasis rosea. It is an acute self-limiting condition, with very low recurrence rates. 

Pityriasis rosea/pityriasis circinata is an acute self-limiting papulosquamous disorder. It is commonly seen in children and young adults.

Even though the exact cause is unknown, T-cell mediated immunity and infectious etiology are thought to be responsible for this condition. An association with infectious agents like human herpesvirus-6 (HHV-6) and human herpesvirus-7 (HHV-7) has been found recently.

Clinical features include:

  • Prodrome of a sore throat, gastrointestinal disturbance, fever or arthralgia.
  • Herald patch - Large and conspicuous eruptions on the thigh, upper arm, trunk or neck covered by fine scales

The image given below shows a herald patch.

  • After 5-15 days, it turns into discrete oval lesions, dull pink in color and covered by fine dry silvery-grey scales. 
  • These secondary lesions occur as macules and papules that are elliptical or ovular, symmetric, and commonly involve the thorax, back, and abdomen.
  • It is followed by a marginal collarette of scale with a central wrinkling and atrophy. The collarettes of the scales are attached peripherally. It is also called a hanging curtain sign.

The image given below shows collarette scales.

  • The long axes of the lesions characteristically follow the lines of skin tension parallel to the ribs in a Christmas tree pattern on the upper chest and back.

 The images given below show a Christmas tree pattern along the lines of skin tension on the back and the chest.

The rashes of pityriasis rosea usually resolve by 8 weeks.

Dermatoscopy shows:

  • Yellowish background-color
  • Peripheral arrangement of the scales
  • Patchy distribution of loosely arranged dotted vessels

Histopathology shows:

  • Superficial perivascular dermatitis with focal parakeratosis, hyperplasia and spongiosis in the epidermis.
  • Extravasated red blood cells along with a perivascular infiltrate and subcorneal pustules are seen in the dermis

No treatment is required for asymptomatic cases. Application of irritants to the skin and tanning should be avoided, since it may result in pigmentary changes. Emollients and antihistaminics are useful to relieve the itching. If symptomatic, various agents are used like:

  • First-line agents: If severe pruritus or poor cosmetic appeal is present
    • Topical steroids
    • Narrowband UV-B therapy
  • Second-line agents: For a rapid resolution of the lesions, in view of the probable infectious aetiology.
    • Antivirals like acyclovir
    • Macrolides like erythromycin

Pityriasis rosea within the first few weeks of gestation may cause premature delivery and fetal demise. Pityriasis rosea-like eruptions were reported after ingestion of drugs like gold, captopril, aspirin, metronidazole and clonidine and after vaccinations like BCG, influenza, diphtheria, hepatitis B, and Pneumococcus.

Related Pearl: Types of scales associated with dermatological conditions

Types of Scales and Associated Diseases

Type of Scale

Associated Disease

Collarette scale

Its is a fine, peripherally attached and centrally detached scale at the edge of an inflammatory lesion. It is seen in Pityriasis rosea.

Fish-like scales

They are seen in Ichthyosis Vulgaris (Ichthyos = Fish). Ichthyotic scales are large and polygonal.

Silvery/mica-like scales

They are characteristic of processes involving parakeratosis, especially psoriasis. The silvery color is due to reflection of light at several air–keratin interfaces.

Yellow/Greasy scale

Seborrheic dermatitis

Leaf-like scale

Pemphigus foliaceous

Powdery, branny, fine scales

Pityriasis Versicolor

questions.text: The histopathological section of the cardiac tissue of an 82-year-old man shows some pigmentation, as seen below. Intracellular accumulation of which of the following is likely to be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Intracellular accumulation of lipofuscin (brown lipid) is seen in this patient. 

Lipofuscin or lipochrome is also known as the wear-and-tear pigment. It is an insoluble, brownish-yellow, granular intracellular material, which accumulates in various tissues like the heart, liver, and brain. It is seen in normal ageing patients. Accumulation of the brown pigment in large amounts can give a characteristic appearance to the tissue called brown atrophy.  

It is derived from lipid peroxidation of polyunsaturated lipids indicating free radical injury. Not injurious to the cell or its functions. It is seen in cells undergoing slow, regressive changes. The image of lipofuscin is given below.

Option B: Anthracosis leads to accumulations of carbon/coal dust pigment which is seen as black accumulations in the tissues of the lungs and not the heart. The following image shows anthracosis with deposition of black carbon particles, within the cytoplasm of macrophages.

Option C: Melanin is brown-black in color which occurs as a result of oxidation of tyrosine in melanocytes, as shown in the following histopathology of a lymph node. 

Option D: Hemosiderin is a haemoglobin-derived, golden-yellow to brown, granular or crystalline pigment. It is one of the major storage forms of iron and can be seen in iron-overload states like hemochromatosis. The following image shows extensive intra-alveolar hemosiderin deposition following pulmonary haemorrhage.

questions.text: A young female presents with dyspareunia, mucopurulent vaginal discharge and dysuria. She mentions having unprotected sexual intercourse about a week ago. Gram-staining of the discharge shows the following image. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The image depicts microscopic findings of gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes in a stained smear from the mucopurulent discharge. The patient complains of mucopurulent discharge, dyspareunia, increased urinary urgency and frequency after one week of unprotected intercourse.  This clinical scenario along with the image indicates infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted disease caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It uses pilli in adhesion to the urethra or other mucosal surfaces. The cocci penetrate the intracellular spaces to reach the subepithelial tissue by the third day of infection. The incubation period is 2-8 days.

The major symptoms include vaginal discharge, dyspareunia and dysuria, usually without urinary frequency or urgency. The specific symptoms seen in males and females are as follows:

In females:

About half the female patients remain asymptomatic. But, patients typically present with urethritis, cervical discharge, pruritus, dysuria, and intermenstrual bleeding.

The ectocervix and vagina are not usually affected in adults as the stratified squamous epithelium is resistant to infection by the cocci. The acidic pH of vaginal secretions is also protective. The principal sites of invasion for gonococcal infection are the columnar and transitional epithelium.

The initial infection involves the cervix uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands, skene glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes. Unilateral pain and swelling over the labia may be caused by the inflammation of the Bartholin glands.

Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis may lead to sterility. Other complications are tubo-ovarian abscesses and ectopic pregnancies. Rarely peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz Hugh Curtis syndrome). The patient presents with right upper quadrant pain and tenderness with abnormal liver function tests.

In males :

  • Acute urethritis: This infection may extend along the urethra to involve the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis.
  • Genital discharge: It is mucopurulent that can be described as that resembling 'flow of seed' (semen).
  • Strictures: Chronic urethritis may lead to stricture formation.
  • Water-can perineum: The infection may spread to the periurethral tissues causing abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses.

Lab diagnosis:

The discharge is collected and subjected to Gram's stain which reveals gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. Stuart's transport medium is used. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. Specifically, Thayer-Martin agar is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

Treatment

According to CDC guidelines (2021), treatment of uncomplicated gonococcal infections is as follows:

  • Weight <150 kg – Ceftriaxone 500 mg intramuscular (IM) in a single dose
  • Weight ≥150 kg – Ceftriaxone 1 g intramuscular (IM) in a single dose

The doses of ceftriaxone are higher than the previous guidelines as the gonococcal minimum inhibitory concentrations (MICs) are rising worldwide. BASHH (British Association for Sexual Health and HIV) in the United Kingdom also recommends higher doses of ceftriaxone of about 500 mg or 1g along with azithromycin because it would result in fewer failures.

Concurrent chlamydial infection must also be treated unless it has been excluded by molecular testing. First-line drugs used are as follows:

  • Oral azithromycin 1g single dose
  • Oral doxycycline 100 mg BD for 7 days (non-pregnant patients only)

The third-generation cephalosporins are contraindicated in patients with a history of IgE-mediated penicillin allergy. The treatment includes:

  • Gemifloxacin 320mg oral + Azithromycin 2g oral
  • Gentamicin 240mg (IM)+ Azithromycin 2g oral

The sexual partners of the patient must be treated to reduce the risk of recurrence. Expedited partner therapy refers to the index patient delivering therapy to one's own partners. However, this type of empirical therapy ignores the importance of direct counseling.

 

Other options :

Option A: Chlamydial infection on Gram's staining will show leukocytes without organisms.

Option B: Trichomonas vaginalis infections show motile trichomonads on wet mount, as shown in the image below. 

Option C. Gardnerella vaginalis/ bacterial vaginosis shows presence of clue cells, as shown in the image below.

questions.text: Where does 5-fluorouracil act in the image given below?
questions.solution:
5-Fluorouracil is an S-phase inhibitor. DNA synthesis occurs in the S-phase of the mitosis cycle. 5-FU acts via two different pathways depending on dose: G1- S-phase cell cycle arrest and apoptosis at a higher dose and G2-M-phase cell cycle arrest at a low dose.

5-FU:

  • Converted in the body to the corresponding nucleotide 5-deoxyuridine monophosphate which forms a covalent ternary complex with methyl-THFA and thymidylate synthase resulting in irreversible inhibition of thymidylate synthase.
  • Failure of DNA synthesis occurs due to the non-availability of thymidylate.
  • Inhibition of TS by 5-FU depends on THFA, infusion of leucovorin will enhance the efficacy of this drug. Cisplatin and oxaliplatin also synergize with this drug.
  • Rapidly dividing cells are most commonly affected, but resting cells are also affected.
  • Used as an anticancer drug for many solid cancers such as colon, rectum, stomach, pancreas, liver, urinary bladder, head and neck. Topical preparations are used in BCC and actinic keratosis.
  • Toxicity includes myelosuppression, mucositis, diarrhoea, nausea, and vomiting. Peripheral neuropathy may also occur.

Cell cycle progression is driven by the formation of complexes of proteins called cyclins and associated enzymes known as cyclin-dependent kinases. Cyclins are synthesized only during the cell cycle to regulate the progression of the cell across the phases of the cell cycle, while cyclin-dependent kinases are constitutively present irrespective of the cell cycle.

Cyclins D, E, A, and B appear sequentially during the cell cycle and bind to one or more CDKs.

  1. G1-S transition: Cyclin D-CDK4, cyclin D-CDK6, and cyclin E-CDK2.
  2. S-phase: Cyclin A-CDK1 and cyclin A-CDK2.
  3. G2-M transition: Cyclin B-CDK1.

CDK inhibitors (CDKIs) enforce the cell cycle checkpoints. There are several families of CDKIs:

  • CDKIs that broadly inhibit multiple CDKs: p21, p27, p57
  • CDKIs that inhibit CDK4 and CDK6: p15, p16, p18, and p19

The image below shows the different checkpoints and cell cycle regulators :

CDK : Cyclin-dependent kinase

 

Related Pearl: Classification of antineoplastic drugs

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with blurred vision. All routine examinations were done. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Histopathological image shows acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules suggestive of nodular glomerulosclerosis/intercapillary glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease, which occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

Three renal lesions are encountered in diabetic nephropathy:

  • Glomerular lesions:
    • Capillary basement membrane thickening
    • Diffuse mesangial sclerosis
    • Nodular glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease
  • Renal vascular lesions, principally hyaline arteriolosclerosis
  • Pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis

Renal histopathology in

  • Amyloidosis: Glomerular deposits appearing as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid
  • Lupus nephritis: Immune complex deposits in the mesangium or along the entire basement membrane (wire loop lesions), with mesangial cell proliferation
  • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: Focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall; lipid droplets in the sclerosed area.

questions.text: Which of the following tendons is most commonly affected in the shoulder impingement syndrome?
questions.solution:
Supraspinatus is the most commonly affected tendon in shoulder impingement syndrome. 

It is also called supraspinatus syndrome, painful arc syndrome, and swimmer's shoulder and occurs when the tendons of the rotator cuff muscles become irritated and inflamed as they pass through the subacromial space. This can result in pain, weakness, and loss of movement at the shoulder.

Causes of impingement syndrome:

  • Supraspinatus tendinitis (Common)
  • Complete or partial rupture of the rotator cuff
  • Osteoarthritis of the acromioclavicular joint

Clinical features:

  • Subacute tendinitis or painful arc syndrome: Anterior shoulder pain after vigorous activity. Treatment is with avoidance of initiating activity, NSAIDs and physiotherapy.
  • Chronic tendinitis: Recurrent attacks of subacute tendinitis and pain is worse at night. 
  • Cuff disruption: There is progressive fibrosis and disruption of the cuff leading to a partial or full-thickness tear. Treatment includes acromioplasty and repair of rotator cuff.

The following video shows the action of the subscapularis through the subacrominal space:

Related Pearl: Tests for anterior shoulder dislocation

Bryant’s test: Anterior axillary fold is at a lower level on the dislocated side.

 

Dugas test: The patient is made to place the hand on the opposite shoulder. The examiner then applies gentle overpressure on the flexed elbow to make it touch the chest. In shoulder dislocation, the elbow cannot be made to touch the chest. 

 

Hamilton ruler test: In a normal shoulder, a ruler (scale) placed on the lateral side of the arm will not touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion at the same time. In anterior shoulder dislocation, the ruler will simultaneously touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion. 

 

 

Callaway Test: The vertical circumference of the axilla is increased on the dislocated side as compared to the normal side.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding iodine isotopes?

choices.text: I-125 is used for treating thyroid metastasis
I-131 is used in functional thyroid scan

questions.solution:
The half-life of I-125 is 60 days.

Salient points about I-125:

  • Half-life = 60days
  • Commonly used in brachytherapy in the treatment of cancer especially in prostate cancer
  • It is also used in radioimmunoassay to show the presence of hormone in tiny quantities

Other Iodine radioisotopes:

Iodine radioisotope I123 I131
Half-life 12- 14 hrs 8-10 days
Radiation exposure Low High
Radiation emission Gamma rays Beta and Gamma rays
Used in imaging Imaging of Lingual thyroids / anatomical and physiological function of the thyroid Screen and treat patients with differentiated thyroid cancers for metastatic disease

Related Pearl: Half life of radio isotopes

Radioisotope Half-life
Cobalt 60 5.2 years
Iridium 192 74 days
Iodine 131 8 days
Iodine 125 60 days
Iodine 123 13 hours
Iodine 132 3 hours 
Cesium 137 30 years
Technetium 99m 6 Hours
18 FDG 110 minutes
Radon 222 3.8 days

Strontium- 90 28 years
